title: 113_s2952
content: The "Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2014" establishes the Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking in the executive branch. The Commission on Evidence-Based Policymaking is comprised of 15 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Appointments include individuals with expertise in academic research, data management, confidentiality, privacy, and program administration. Three members appointed by the Minority Leader of the House of Representatives should have expertise in academic research, data management, confidentiality, and privacy. Three members appointed by the Majority Leader of the Senate should also have similar expertise. Three members appointed by the Majority and Minority Leaders of the Senate should have expertise in academic research, data management, confidentiality, and privacy. The Commission appointments prioritize expertise in economics, statistics, program evaluation, data security, and confidentiality. The President selects the chairperson, and the Speaker of the House selects the co-chairperson. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment, with members serving for the Commission's duration. Vacancies are to be filled promptly. Members of the Commission serve without pay and are entitled to travel expenses while performing their duties. Vacancies in the Commission do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will conduct a study on data inventory, infrastructure, and statistical protocols related to Federal policymaking. This study aims to integrate administrative data for program evaluation and policy research by qualified researchers. The Commission will study data infrastructure and protocols for Federal policymaking, including creating a clearinghouse for program and survey data. Recommendations will be made on modifying data infrastructure, incorporating outcomes measurement, and implementing rigorous impact analysis into program design. The Commission will study relevant administrative datasets for program evaluation and Federal policy-making, survey dataset linkages, legal barriers, data-sharing infrastructure, self-funding for a clearinghouse, and criteria for qualified researchers and officials. The Commission will study relevant administrative datasets for program evaluation and Federal policy-making, including determining qualified researchers and officials who should have access to data, limitations on data use, privacy protection, using data for program improvement, and incentives for interagency data sharing. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation or administrative actions based on the study. The report must be submitted within 15 months of a majority of Commission members being appointed. The term "administrative data" is defined in this section. The term "administrative data" refers to information generated or collected by an agency in carrying out a Federal program, including various measures and indicators as defined in title 31, United States Code. SEC. 5. OPERATION AND POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission shall receive advice and consultation from various agencies including the Office of Management and Budget, Bureau of the Census, Internal Revenue Service, Bureau of Economic Analysis, Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Health and Human Services, Department of Agriculture, Department of Housing and Urban Development, Social Security Administration, Department of Education, and Department of Justice. The Commission, including the Department of Education and Department of Justice, shall meet within 30 days of majority appointment. The chairperson will determine meeting times, and rules of procedure will be established with a quorum requirement. Hearings may be conducted for Commission purposes. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, contract with government and private agencies, use the United States mails, and accept gifts or donations. The Commission has the authority to receive donations of services or property. The Director of the Census can contract with the National Academy of Public Administration for administration. Principal statistical agencies can provide funds, not exceeding $2,000,000, for the Commission's operations. The term "statistical agency" is defined in a report by the Office of Management and Budget titled "Statistical Programs of the United States Government, Fiscal Year 2014". SEC. 6. PERSONNEL. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the chairperson with the concurrence of the co-chairperson, paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff and procure temporary services as needed. The Commission's Director is appointed at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Staff may be hired at rates not exceeding the annual rate of basic pay for a comparable position under the General Schedule. The Commission will terminate within 18 months of the Act's enactment.
